titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

body.p: Mrs Webbe and Penelope went away after breakfast, and Kathleen soon followed their example. The morning was filled with the mingled employments of preparing for our own departure. At 2.30 p.m. Ella and I left the Castle in the small motor open, thought the sky was overcast. As we went out of the gates, the people, largely children & youths, were streaming into the Park, which stands open on Easter Monday to unhindered admission.

We motored without incident to Ripon via. Piercebridge, and there called on the Dean, whom we found attendant on a sick wife. We then made our way to Sorley Hall, where we had tea with Sir John and Lady Barron. She was rather "full of" the ecclesiastical storm in the Protestant Episcopal Church of U.S.A., in which her father, Dr Parkes, is a central figure. She said that he was induced to preach the sermon which has so greatly moved Bishop Manning by Bishop Lawrence. This, if indeed it be the case, is interesting. We continued our journey to Sandbeck, but did not arrive before 9 p.m. being greatly delayed by the congestion in the street of Wetherby, where races had been proceeding, & by the difficulty of finding our route after leaving Doncaster. However we did finally arrive, & were welcomed by Lord & Lady Scarbrough with whom were two guests, one a Christ Church Science don.
